component:ember-vega/components/vega-vis.title: VegaVis
component:ember-vega/components/vega-vis.text: A component for rendering a Vega visualization. {{vega-vis vis=vis config=config data=data spec=spec height=100 width=200 padding=(hash top=10 bottom=10 left=10 right=10) background="#000" enableHover=true rendererType="svg" logLevel="None" events=(hash click=(action "click")) signalEvents=(hash foo=(action "fooSignalChanged")) onParseError=(action "parseError") onNewVis=(action "newVisCreated") }}

attributes.name: VegaVis
attributes.description:
A component for rendering a Vega visualization.

{{vega-vis
   vis=vis
   config=config
   data=data
   spec=spec
   height=100
   width=200
   padding=(hash top=10 bottom=10 left=10 right=10)
   background="#000"
   enableHover=true
   rendererType="svg"
   logLevel="None"
   events=(hash click=(action "click"))
   signalEvents=(hash foo=(action "fooSignalChanged"))
   onParseError=(action "parseError")
   onNewVis=(action "newVisCreated")
}}

methods.name: isSamePadding
methods.description: Equality check between two padding objects.

methods.name: isSameData
methods.description: Simple equality check between two objects.

methods.name: isSameSpec
methods.description: Equality check by comparing two JSON.stringify'ied objects.

methods.name: isChangeSet
methods.description: Determine if a value is a vega-dataflow changeset or not.

methods.name: didReceiveAttrs
methods.description: Updates visualization due to attr changes. If the spec changes, the old visualization will be removed and a whole new visualization will be created.

methods.name: didInsertElement
methods.description: Executes creation of visualization.

methods.name: createVis
methods.description: Creates a visualization from the spec and attrs. Thrown errors will clear the visualization and execute onParseError

params.name: spec
params.description: The specification used to create a Vega.View instance

methods.name: clearVis
methods.description: Prepare the visualization to be removed.

methods.name: _normalizeData
methods.description:
Data is expected to be an object containing name/dataset pairs.

In case the data is actually an array, convert it to an object.

params.name: data
params.description: Datasets used for rendering the Vega.View instance

methods.name: updateData
methods.description:
Update a dataset. The value can be an array, a function, or a changeset instance.

Where value is an array, the array of values will replace the existing dataset by creating a changeset instance.

Where value is a changeset instance, the changeset will be set on the Vega.View instance via thechange` method.

Where value is a function, the Vega.View instance, current dataset "live" array, and a changeset instance will be passed as arguments. Inserting and removing of data in the changeset, and setting the changeset on the vega instance will be the responsibility of the function. Refer to the documentation below for helper methods for inserting, removing, or changing data.

vega.change https://github.com/vega/vega-view#view_change vega.insert https://github.com/vega/vega-view#view_insert vega.remove https://github.com/vega/vega-view#view_remove

An example of the function, removing odd-numbered indexed datum:

// component.js

myData(vis, data, change) {
    change.remove((datum) => datum.id % 2 === 0);
    vis.change('my-data', change);
},

data: computed(function() {
    return {
        'my-data': this.myData.bind(this)
    }
})

{{vega-vis spec=spec data=data}}

params.name: value
params.description: A function that accepts a changeset, an array of values, or a changeset instance.

methods.name: willDestroyElement
methods.description: Remove the visualization during before the component is destroyed.

methods.name: visRun
methods.description: Invoke visualization run method to render the visualization. Will only run when component hasn't been destroyed or in the process of being destroyed.

methods.name: _invokeEventMethod
methods.description: Abstract method to help add/remove events/signals to the visulzation.

params.name: method
params.description: Name of method, such as addEventListener or removeSignalListener

params.name: events
params.description: KV pairs of event/signal names and functions

methods.name: addEvents
methods.description: Adds event listeners contained in an events object.

params.name: events
params.description: KV pairs of event names and functions. https://github.com/vega/vega-view#view_addEventListener

methods.name: removeEvents
methods.description: Removes event listeners contained in an events object.

params.name: events
params.description: KV pairs of event names and functions. https://github.com/vega/vega-view#view_removeEventListener

methods.name: addSignalEvents
methods.description: Adds signal event listeners contained in a signalevents object.

params.name: signalEvents
params.description: KV pairs of signal evnet names and functions. https://github.com/vega/vega-view#view_addSignalListener

methods.name: removeSignalEvents
methods.description: Removes signal event listeners contained in a signalevents object.

params.name: signalEvents
params.description: KV pairs of signal evnet names and functions. https://github.com/vega/vega-view#view_addSignalListener

accessors.name: spec
accessors.description:
Specification of Vega visualization.

Used to create Vega visualization's runtime.

Vega Docs: Specification

accessors.name: data
accessors.description:
KV pairs of dataset name and array of values, a changeset, or a function.

Where value is an array, the array of values will replace the existing dataset by creating a changeset instance.

Where value is a changeset instance, the changeset will be set on the Vega.View instance via thechange` method.

Where value is a function, the Vega.View instance, current dataset "live" array, and a changeset instance will be passed as arguments. Inserting and removing of data in the changeset, and setting the changeset on the vega instance will be the responsibility of the function. Refer to the documentation below for helper methods for inserting, removing, or changing data.

Vega Docs: View.change Vega Docs: View.insert Vega Docs: View.remove

An example of the function, removing odd-numbered indexed datum:

// component.js

myData(vis, data, change) {
    change.remove((datum) => datum.id % 2 === 0);
    vis.change('my-data', change);
},

data: computed(function() {
    return {
        'my-data': this.myData.bind(this)
    }
})

{{vega-vis spec=spec data=data}}

Vega Docs: Data

accessors.name: fastboot
accessors.description: Determines if the component is being rendered in Fastboot.

arguments.name: vis
arguments.description:
Vega visualization instance.

Vega Docs: View

arguments.name: config
arguments.description:
Defines default visual values to set a visualization’s theme.

Passed to create Vega visualization's runtime.

Vega Docs: Config

arguments.name: width
arguments.description:
Width of the visualization in pixels. If one is not defined, the width defined in the spec will be used.

Passed to view.width method.

Vega Docs: Specification Vega Docs: View.width

arguments.name: height
arguments.description:
Height of the visualization in pixels. If one is not defined, the height defined in the spec will be used.

Passed to view.height method

Vega Docs: Specification Vega Docs: View.height

arguments.name: background
arguments.description:
Vega visualization's background color.

Passed to view.background method.

Vega Docs: Specification Vega Docs: View.background

arguments.name: padding
arguments.description:
Vega visualization's padding in pixels.

Passed to view.padding method.

Vega Docs: Specification Vega Docs: View.padding

arguments.name: enableHover
arguments.description:
Enable hover event processing. If an object, properties hoverSet and updateSet will be passed when enabling hover event processing.

vis.hover(enableHover.hoverSet, enableHover.updateSet)

Vega Docs: View.hover

arguments.name: onNewVis
arguments.description: Method to execute when a new visualziation has been created.

arguments.name: onParseError
arguments.description: Method to execute when creating a visualization throws an error.

arguments.name: rendererType
arguments.description:
Render Vega visualization with svg or canvas.

Vega Docs: View.renderer

arguments.name: logLevel
arguments.description:
Set the Vega visualization log level.

Valid values: None, Warn, Info, Debug

Vega Docs: View.logLevel

arguments.name: events
arguments.description:
Events to add to vega view instance.

Vega Docs: View.addEventListener Vega Docs: View.removeEventListener

arguments.name: signalEvents
arguments.description:
Signal events to add to Vega View instance.

Vega Docs: View.addSignalListener Vega Docs: View.removeSignalListener

arguments.name: container
arguments.description:
Container element for rendering the Vega View instance.

The visualization can be rendered in a different container if desired. This helps with reducing the number of elements.

The example also sets the tagName property to an empty string, this effectively prevents vega-vis from creating its own element.

{{#foo-thing as |element|}}
    {{vega-vis spec=spec container=element tagName=""}}
{{/foo-thing}}

component:ember-vega/components/vega-vis.title: VegaVisContainer
component:ember-vega/components/vega-vis.text: A component for accessing the component's dimensions. {{#vega-vis-container as |ui|}} {{vega-vis height=(div ui.dimensions.width 4.259259259) width=ui.dimensions.width spec=spec data=data }} {{/vega-vis-container}}

attributes.name: VegaVisContainer
attributes.description:
A component for accessing the component's dimensions.

{{#vega-vis-container as |ui|}}
    {{vega-vis
        height=(div ui.dimensions.width 4.259259259)
        width=ui.dimensions.width
        spec=spec
        data=data
    }}
{{/vega-vis-container}}

methods.name: computeComponentDimensions
methods.description: Get the return value of element.getBoundingClientRect().

methods.name: recomputeComponentDimensions
methods.description: Set the return value of element.getBoundingClientRect() as dimensions property.

methods.name: didInsertElement
methods.description: Store and set the window resize event listener and recompute the dimensions.

methods.name: willDestroyElement
methods.description: Remove the window resize event listener.

accessors.name: dimensions
accessors.description:
Dimensions of the component - return value of element.getBoundingClientRect().

The dimensions can be used to pass the width and height of a vega-vis component.

It's useful with aspect ratios.

MDN Docs: Element.getBoundingClientRect

accessors.name: fastboot
accessors.description: Determines if the component is being rendered in Fastboot.

template:application-tailwind.title: Your Tailwind styles
template:application-tailwind.text: Your Tailwind styles A reference for every generated class in your app.

template:docs/components/index.title: Components
template:docs/components/index.text: Components ember-vega provides components to help interact with Vega.

template:docs/components/vega-vis-contai.title: Vega Vis Container
template:docs/components/vega-vis-contai.text: Vega Vis Container This component yields an object that contains three properties: element - the component's element. dimensions - component element's getBoundingClientRect. vis - a composed vega-vis component Dimensions Property The dimensions is bound to the window resize event, so whenever the window resizes, the dimensions will be updated. It's useful for computing aspect ratios making vega-vis responsive. By default, ui.vis will have its height and width properties set to dimensions.height and dimensions.width, respectively. Alternatively, a spec can have use the containerSize expression to make the visualization responsive. The example below show's width and height signals that update the when the windows resize event is triggered. If you have a spec that makes use of this feature, there is no need to use vega-vis-container component in this scenario. { "signals": [ { "name": "width", "update": "(containerSize()[0] || 400)", "on": [{ "events": {"source": "window", "type": "resize"}, "update": "containerSize()[0]" }] }, { "name": "height", "update": "(containerSize()[1] || 200)", "on": [{ "events": {"source": "window", "type": "resize"}, "update": "containerSize()[1]" }] } ] } Element Property With the element property, the vega-vis can render the visualization in a different element from it's own. This helps with reducing the number of elements in the DOM and can help with debugging. Note that a tagName property is passed to vega-vis, along with the visContainer. Since vega-vis will be rendering the visualization in a different element, setting the tagName to an empty string will prevent vega-vis from creating an element of its own. By default, the yielded ui.vis will have visContainer set to ui.element and tagName set to an empty string. Vis Property The vis property is a composed vega-vis component with some defaults set: The height and width is the yielded dimensions.height and dimensions.width. This will automatically make vega-vis responsive. The vega-vis tagName property is an empty string and visContainer property is the yielded element. This automatically reduces the number of elements. Since vis is a composed component, any of the defaults can be overriden.

template:docs/components/vega-vis.title: Vega Vis
template:docs/components/vega-vis.text: Vega Vis This component creates and renders a Vega.js visualization and provides an interface for passing properties to the Vega View instance. A vis property is exposed to enable direct interaction with the Vega.js View instance. {{vega-vis vis=vis config=config data=data spec=spec height=100 width=200 padding=(hash top=10 bottom=10 left=10 right=10) background="#000" enableHover=true rendererType="svg" logLevel="None" events=(hash click=(action "click")) signalEvents=(hash foo=(action "fooSignalChanged")) onParseError=(action "parseError") onNewVis=(action "newVisCreated") }} Refer to the for more information on the attributes. Rendering a Visualization The only required property is the spec, a plain Javascript Object, which instructs Vega.js how to render a visualization. Refer to Vega.js Docs: Spec for more information. The basic structure of the spec looks like: { "description": "A specification outline example.", "width": 500, "height": 200, "padding": 5, "autosize": "pad", "signals": [], "data": [], "scales": [], "projections": [], "axes": [], "legends": [], "marks": [] } The spec MUST contain data. spec.data MAY contain multiple datasets, which has definitions and transforms that define the data to load and how to process it. Each dataset in spec.data MAY contain values, which will be overwritten if data property passed to the component contains a matching dataset. Refer to Vega.js Docs: Data for more information. Dynamic Data The data property is a mechanism for dynamic data visualization rendering. Each dataset must also be defined inspec.data. Spec { "data": [ {"name": "foo"}, {"name": "bar"} ] } Data { "foo": [], "bar": [] } Changes to the data property will update the visualization. The dataset in a data property may be one of three values: An array. A function. A Vega.js Changeset instance. In order to update the visualization, the data property must be a new object. Dataset as an Array As an array, the dataset will be processed for rendering the visualization. The dataset will replace the previous dataset. Copies of the data should be made because Vega.js Vis will mutate the dataset, so don't pass in the source. Dataset as a Function A dataset as a function provides more flexibility and control. The function is passed three arguments: vis - the Vega.js View instance. data - the current dataset corresponding to the dataset's name/key. change - a changeset instance is an interface for modifying/removing/inserting data into the existing dataset. Dataset as a Vega.js Changeset A Vega.js Changeset instance will be applied on the Vega.js View instance to update the dataset with the matching name/key. Changing Data with Vega.js Changeset Below are some examples of modifying, removing, inserting, and replacing data by using Vega.js Changeset. Assume that the change is within a dataset as a function. Modify Data Modify a data object. changeset.modify accepts a data object, that exists in vega, or a function to filter for data that needs to be updated. function change(vis, data, change) { change.modify(data[0], 'someField', 123); change.modify(function(d) { return d.someField !== 456; }, 'someField', 456) vis.change('my-dataset', change); } Removing Data Remove data object(s). changeset.remove accepts a data object, an array of objects, or a function to filter for data that needs to be removed. function remove(vis, data, change) { change.remove(data[0]); change.remove([data[1], data[2]]); change.remove(function(d) { return d.someField >= 123; }); vis.change('my-dataset', change); } Alternatively, the Vega.js View instance has a helper function, where the second argument is what changeset.remove accepts. function remove(vis, data, change) { vis.remove('my-dataset', data[0]); } Inserting/Adding Data Insert/add data object(s). 'changeset.insert' accepts a data object or an array of objects; function insert(vis, data, change) { change.insert({...obj}); change.insert([{...obj2}]); vis.change('my-dataset', change); } Alternatively, the Vega.js instance has a helper function, where the second argument is what changeset.insert accepts. function insert(vis, data, change) { vis.insert('my-dataset', {...obj}); } Replacing Data Replace data object(s) or datsets. changeset supports combination of all the methods above. function replace(vis, data, change) { change.remove(() => true).insert([...obj]); vis.change('my-dataset', change); }

template:docs/index.title: Introduction
template:docs/index.text: Introduction Built on D3.js, Vega.js is a visualization grammar, a declarative language for creating, saving, and sharing interactive visualization designs. With Vega.js, you can describe the visual appearance and interactive behavior of a visualization in a JSON format, and generate web-based views using Canvas or SVG. ember-vega provides components and enables importing of the vega lib. Resources Vega.js Documentation Vega.js Examples Vega.js Tutorial Vega.js Debugging Tutorial

template:docs/usage.title: Usage
template:docs/usage.text: Usage Installation Installing ember-vega with ember install will automatically run the ember-vega blueprint to install additional dependencies into your application. If installing with yarn add or npm install, be sure to run the blueprint afterwards. With Ember: ember install ember-vegaWith Yarn: yarn add --dev ember-vega && ember generate ember-vegaWith NPM: npm install --dev ember-vega && ember generate ember-vega Import Vega.js can be imported after installation. import vega, { changeset, parse, View } from 'vega'; Components This addon provides two components for rendering visualizations with Vega.js.

template:docs/vega-lite.title: Vega-Lite
template:docs/vega-lite.text: Vega-Lite Vega-Lite is a high-level grammar of interactive graphics. It provides a concise JSON syntax for rapidly generating visualizations to support analysis. Vega-Lite specifications can be compiled to Vega specifications. -- https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/ Think of Vega-Lite's specifications as the simpler version of Vega.js specifications. Resources Vega-Lite Documentation Vega-Lite Examples Vega-Lite Tutorial Installation Vega-Lite is not installed with ember-vega, so you will need to add it as a dependency in your app. Note: Use ember-auto-import to simplify importing node modules. With NPM: npm install vega-liteWith Yarn: yarn add vega-lite Usage Import vega-lite and use it to compile a Vega-Lite specification to a Vega.js specification. Your Component: import Component from '@ember/component'; import { computed } from '@ember/object'; import { compile } from 'vega-lite'; export default Component.extend({ spec: computed(function() { const vegaLiteSpec = { /* ... */ }; return compile(vegaLiteSpec).spec; }) }); Your Component's Template: {{vega-vis spec=spec}}
